title: A-a O₂ Gradient
description: Assesses degree of shunt and ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch through the alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient

parameters.name: fio2
parameters.description: Inspired oxygen fraction (0.21 for room air)

parameters.name: patm
parameters.description: Atmospheric pressure (default: 760 mmHg at sea level)

ranges.interpretation: Preserved alveolar function. Normal values for young adults are 5-10 mmHg, which may increase with age.
Mild V/Q mismatch or minimal shunt. Consider causes such as mild atelectasis or early pulmonary edema.
Moderate V/Q mismatch or shunt. Suggests significant lung disease such as pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or pulmonary embolism.
Severe V/Q mismatch or significant shunt. Indicates severe lung disease such as ARDS, extensive pneumonia, or intracardiac shunt.

references: Helmholz HF Jr. The abbreviated alveolar air equation. Chest. 1979;75(6):748.
Story DA. Alveolar oxygen partial pressure, alveolar carbon dioxide partial pressure, and the alveolar gas equation. Anesthesiology. 1996;84(4):1011.
McFarlane MJ, Imperiale TF. Use of the alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient in the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. Am J Med. 1994;96(1):57-62.
Mellemgaard K. The alveolar-arterial oxygen difference: its size and components in normal man. Acta Physiol Scand. 1966;67(1):10-20.
formula: A-a = PAO₂ - PaO₂, where PAO₂ = (Patm - PH₂O) × FiO₂ - PaCO₂/RQ. Patm = 760 mmHg, PH₂O = 47 mmHg, RQ = 0.8
notes: PAO₂ calculated by the alveolar gas equation
Normal gradient in young adults: 5-10 mmHg
Increases approximately 1 mmHg per decade after middle age
Useful for differentiating hypoxemia due to hypoventilation vs. lung disease
Normal gradient with hypoxemia suggests hypoventilation
